content:
I've edited the puzzle as follows:

Goal
* Replaced {{V - 1}} with [[V]]{{- 1}}.

Cases
* Inserted two new pairs of cases:

  • Test/Validator 4: More robbers than vaults, to cover the scenario [[R]] > [[V]].
  
  • Test/Validator 5: Vaults with same stats, to cover the scenario where some vaults have the same stats (i.e. two vaults share the same [[C]] and [[N]]).
If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

I got sudden run-time errors while I was solving this with Swift language only in test case 3 and 4. I finally realized there were additional white spaces after first two input lines( for R and V ) which caused parsing error for converting String to Int. I can fix them by using trim function, but those codes were given by default. Can you remove additional white spaces on test case 3 and 4 ?

Hello, as I tried to solve the puzzle, I wondered if the phrase "Once he finishes one vault, he moves on to the next vault of greater index which nobody has worked on yet" shouldn't be replaced by "Once he finishes one vault, he moves on to the next vault of smallest index which nobody has worked on yet" ?

That's a lot easier to understand than when I last read it. Approved.

Thanks, Chingmann!

Edited the text, main changes being:

1. Changed the time unit from "cycle" to "second". Easier to understand that way.

2. Added that the robbers are foolish and the puzzle requires the player to calculate the time for trying ALL the combinations. (Why doesn't the robber stop and work on the next vault after finding the correct combination for the one he's working on?)

3. Added the assumption that it takes no time to move around.

4. Rewording / reordering for better presentation and clarity.

5. Renamed the validators to be the same as the test cases. More meaningful that way.

6. Added output in stub generator.

At the current puzzle setting (always working on the next greater-index vault) the puzzle is easy. It is ok to consider changing the puzzle type to clash of code, but it is fine for it to remain as a community puzzle.

I imagine that a harder version of the puzzle would involve optimisation (cleverer robbers!) and finding which vaults each robber should work on in order to minimise the total time.
I had to add the difficulty because I did the tags but I did not try the puzzle.
I agree with it, it's more a mathematics problem than a programming one.

As you're going in increasing order, it is the same:
smallest means the minimum index in the set of the remaining vaults,
greater means that if the last one was i, you're going to work on the i+1 vault.
Maybe I could specify that they work the vaults in increasing order.
Done, try now. Thanks for the feedback.

Of course, if you send it I can edit the challenge and upload the image (I don't know if there is any other way to let you add the cover art, if you can do it without my intervention I have no objections).
Trimmed trailing blank space in test case 2 which was blocking resubmission.
As I understand it, "the next vault of greater index which nobody has worked on yet" is v at the begining, and not 0 as you mean.
